snippet: In preparation for a settlement over the 2010 gulf disaster, BP has sharply pruned its global operations to save itself, and now it can plan for its future.
abstract: BP executives breathe collective sigh of relief following $18.7 billion settlement over Gulf of Mexico oil spill; portray settlement as manageable burden after company sold some $38 billion in assets and raised $12 billion in cash in preparation; belt-tightening has shelved company's ambitions to become as large as rival Exxon Mobil, but has also shored up confidence among investors and analysts.

byline.original: By STANLEY REED and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
byline.contributor: Stanley Reed reported from London, and Clifford Krauss from Charleston, W.Va.

lead_paragraph: In preparation for a settlement over the 2010 gulf disaster, BP has sharply pruned its global operations to save itself, and now it can plan for its future.

headline.main: After Settlement, Relief at a Diminished BP
headline.print_headline: Relief at Diminished BP After Spill Settlement
